item.title: [AssortRock_2021_C++_Course] Tree
item.author: ljheric7@gmail.com (Eric Lim)
item.description:
Basic C/C++

유튜브 무료강의 플레이리스트인 “C언어/C++ 무료강의 [2021년 특강]“의 영상을 통해 배운 내용 정리

Tree

Data structure that effectively stores data in hierarchy (can also be seen as a subset of Graph).
Every entry of given data becomes a node and each node can have child node attached to itself. We typically compare the inserted value with the current node and set the smaller one left, bigger one right child node. If we restrict each node to have only two child node or below, we made our tree a Binary Tree.

[Basic Structure representation for Binary Tree]
                        Root
                        /
    				100	                    lv 0
    		50				150             lv 1
    	25		75		125		175         lv 2    -> height = 2
         \       \       /       /
          ------> LeafNode <-----

Due to its quirks, binary tree is used (and modified) for various occasions. One example would be Complete Binary Tree. A Complete binary tree is a binary tree in which all the levels are completely filled except possibly the lowest one, which is filled from the left. Another example would be Full Binary Tree which guarantees that the number of child nodes at the heightest level equals 2^n(n=1,2,…). Implementation would be done through an array; each index representing the nodes id. This way we can caculate a given nodes’ left or right child node id. Also we can go upward and caculate a given nodes’ parent node id as well.

In this tutorial we will focus on normal binary tree.
Binary Search Tree (BST) is what we are going to implement this time. We will perform binary search in a tree structured data instead of ordered container structure. In order to perform binary search on given data we need to make sure that the data set we are dealing with is ordered. We will sort the input values as we get them, and yes this does have performance cost. However when it comes to searching values, we are much faster (its binary search so roughly O(logN)).

One problem that we need to think about is when the given data set is already ordered. This is actually a problem because we form our data assuming that we are the ones how compare and decide where it goes. If every data is in order, than we would end up having this long line of a tree. So people came up with various tricks and algorithms to clean up trees during its lifetime to make it “balanced”. AVL Tree and Red-Black Tree (both very complicated when you first encounter them) are solution to balance out trees evenly. We will not cover them here.

To summerize, BST is …

  • Binary Tree for Binary Searching
  • Insert() -> O(LogN)
  • Find() -> O(LogN)
  • Balancing mechanism is a must to deal with sorted data(or mitigating unbalanced tree structure)
  • Only ordered data set can be “binary searched”, hence why we sort the values as we get them

C++ way of using BST(sort of) : std::map, std::set

Both are known as Associative Containers, meaning that they store data as key-value pair; Data get sorted by there key. std::map and std::set are ususally implemented as Red-Black Tree cppreference(std::map), cppreference(std::set).

As mentioned above, these associative containers need key-value pair as its data input. In C++, std::make_pair() returns that form of data (seeing the code makes this much more easier).

#include <iostream>
#include <string>
#include <map>
#include <set>

using std::map;
using std::make_pair;

struct tStdinfo
{
	wchar_t szName[20];
	unsigned char age;
	unsigned char gender;
	
	tStdinfo() :
		szName{},
		age(0),
		gender(0)
	{}
	
	tStdinfo(const wchar_t* _pName, 
			unsigned char _age, 
			unsigned char _gender) :
		szName{},
		age(_age),
		gender(_gender)
	{
		wcscpy_s(szName, _pName);
	}
};

class customClass
{
	int a;
public:
	customClass(int _a): a(_a){};
	// this is enough considering when comparing anything bigger or same goes together in most cases 
	// (may differ in other lib(or language) implementation)
	bool operator < (const customClass& _a) const {
		if (a < _a.a)
		{
			return true;
		}
		return false;
	}
};

int main(int argc, char** argv)
{

	// "const wchar_t*" is type that refers to
	//  the address of the start of a string data not the string itself
	map<const wchar_t*, tStdinfo> mapData;	
	
	tStdinfo info(L"임정훈", 10, MAN);
	tStdinfo info2(L"몰라", 20, WOMAN);
	
    // its not the actual string that is inserted,
    // address of the string data(inside bss area) gets inside
	mapData.insert(make_pair(L"임정훈", info));	
	mapData.insert(make_pair(L"몰라", info2));
	

	// 이 함수는 리턴으로 입력 때 사용한 pair가 리턴됨
	// 실제 나오는 데이터의 경우 그 데이터를 가르키는 iterator를 반환함
	map<const wchar_t*, tStdinfo>::iterator mapIter;
	
    mapIter = mapData.find(L"임정훈");	
	//	ㄴ> the actual search is based on the size of memory address 
    //	not the actual character inside the string
	
    //wchar_t sz[20] = L"임정훈";
	//mapIter = mapData.find(sz);	-> this would not work bc we are using a different memory address

	// pair의 경우 처음 들어간 데이터는 first, 그다음 묶이는 데이터는 second에 들어간다
	//pair<const wchar_t*, tStdinfo>
	auto firstItem4pair = mapIter->first;		
	// ^ aka (*mapIter).first;
	auto secondItem4pair = mapIter->second;		
	// ^ aka (*mapIter).second;

	_wsetlocale(LC_ALL, L"korean");
	if (mapIter == mapData.end()){
		std::wcout << "없는 데이터 입니다." << std::endl;
	}
	else {
		std::wcout << L"이름: " << mapIter->second.szName << std::endl;
		std::wcout << L"나이: " << mapIter->second.age << std::endl;
		std::wcout << L"성별: " << mapIter->second.gender << std::endl;
		
	}
    
    // bc of the previous map can't figure out the true order of given strings, we should make
	// a new one that actually takes in string data type
	map<std::wstring, tStdinfo> mapData2;

	// what is "std::string"(std::wstring) ?
	//  -> C++ way of controlling "string" data type. Its not just considerd as "char *"
    //  but a full on data type it self 
    std::wstring wstr;
    // = operator will copy the data to its own memory area (heap allocation)
	wstr = L"난 문자 데이터공간에 있다";	
	// += operator can concat string at the end
    wstr += L". 진짜다\n";

	// if using custom class, operator <,>,<=,>=,==,!= must 
    // be defined (with const at the end) so that 
	// it can be used along side with std::map
    // (this applies to anything from stl that compares values during operation)
	map<customClass, int> customClassMap;
	customClass temp(1);
	customClassMap.insert(make_pair(temp, 3));
}

Most of the detail is exlained inside comments (none of them are hard concepts so its fine). So that was how C++ manages to use BST, so now we make our less competent version of it.

Implementation

Here are the plans…

  • Will make templated version
  • Will make our own std::make_pair() and std::map<T1,T2>
  • Will implement Insert(), Erase(), Find(), begin(), end() (and any support functions)
  • We will orient our functionalities to work as Inordered (but leave some breathing room so we can choose other types as well)

The last part is the only part that i didn’t explain. We have inorder, postorder, preorder, and each of them explains the order we go through. We will implement our tree based on inorder traversal, but its trivial adding other orders in afterwards.

  • inorder 중위순회 : L->P->R
  • postorder 전위순회 : P->L->R
  • preorder 후위순회 : L->R->P

To be fair if its not some wacky RedBlack Tree implementing bst is not that hard (just time consuming). Reading the comments inside should be enough for you to understand everything.

enum class NodeType {
	PARENT,
	LCHILD,
	RCHILD,
	END		// acts as size of this enum
};

This is for easy-reading purpose.

template <typename T1, typename T2>
struct tPair{...}

template <typename T1, typename T2>
tPair<T1, T2> make_tPair(const T1& _first, const T2& _second){...}

template <typename T1, typename T2>
struct tBSTNode {...}

template <typename T1, typename T2>
class cBST {...}

These four component is used. tPair and make_tPair is there to replicate std::make_pair<T,K> thats used along side with std::map<>. tBSTNode is obviously representing node for our tree and cBST contains all of the information needed for constructing our bst.

template <typename T1, typename T2>
struct tPair
{
	T1 first;
	T2 second;
};

// replicating std::make_pair<>();
template <typename T1, typename T2>
tPair<T1, T2> make_tPair(const T1& _first, const T2& _second)
{
	return tPair<T1, T2>{_first, _second};
}

This is the implementation for the first two component. Its dead simple.

template <typename T1, typename T2>
struct tBSTNode {
	tPair<T1, T2> pair;
	tBSTNode* arrNode[(int)NodeType::END];

public:
	tBSTNode():
		pair(),
		arrNode{}
	{}
	tBSTNode(const tPair<T1, T2>& _pair):
		pair(_pair),
		arrNode{ nullptr, nullptr, nullptr }
	{}

	tBSTNode(const tPair<T1, T2>& _pair, const tBSTNode* parent, const tBSTNode* lChild, const tBSTNode* rChild) :
		pair(_pair),
		arrNode{ parent, lChild, rChild }
	{}

	bool isRoot() {
		return { this->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT] == nullptr};
	}
	bool isLeft() {
		return { this == arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT]->arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD] };
	}
	bool isRight(const tBSTNode<T1, T2>& _pair) {
		return { this == arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT]->arrNode[(int)NodeType::RCHILD] };
	}
	
	bool isLeaf()
	{
		return { nullptr == arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD] && nullptr == arrNode[(int)NodeType::RCHILD] };
	}

	bool isFull()
	{	// not 100% same as "~isLeaf"
		return { nullptr != arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD] && nullptr != arrNode[(int)NodeType::RCHILD] };
	}
};

This is the implementation for tBSTNode. We have constructors and some helper function telling us the status of given node. arrNode[(int)NodeType::END] is some new way of using enum that i didn’t knew before.

// T1 -> key  T2 -> value
template <typename T1, typename T2>
class cBST {
private:
	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* rootBSTNode;
	int iCount;
	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* deleteNode(tBSTNode<T1, T2>* _node);

public:
	class iterator;
	iterator begin();
	iterator end();
	iterator find(T1 first);
	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* GetInorderSuccessor(tBSTNode<T1, T2>* _node);
	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* GetInorderPredecessor(tBSTNode<T1, T2>* _node);

public:
	bool insert(const tPair<T1, T2>& _pair);
	iterator erase(const iterator& itr);

public:
	cBST() :
		rootBSTNode(nullptr),
		iCount(0)
	{}
	
	class iterator {
	private:
		cBST<T1, T2>* bst;
		tBSTNode<T1, T2>* node;
	public:
		iterator():
			bst(nullptr),
			node(nullptr)
		{}

		iterator(cBST<T1, T2>* _bst, tBSTNode<T1, T2>* _node):
			bst(_bst),
			node(_node)
		{}

		bool operator==(const iterator& _other)
		{
			return (_other.bst == bst && _other.node == node);
		}
		bool operator!=(const iterator& _other)
		{
			return !(*this == _other);
		}

		// this will return "pair" itself
		const tPair<T1, T2>& operator*()
		{
			assert(node);	// check for nullptr aka end()
			return node->pair;
		}
		// this will return the pointer(address) of "pair"
		const tPair<T1, T2>* operator->()
		{
			assert(node);
			return &(node->pair);
		}

		iterator& operator++()
		{
			node = bst->GetInorderSuccessor(node);
			return *this;
		}


		// so that cBST function taking in iterator can
		// access private member(mainly bst) itself from that iterator
		friend class cBST<T1, T2>;	
	}; 
};

Like always we implement iterator inside to replicate the functionalities that std::map<>::iterator have, and we also have operator overloading to work around comparing those iterators.

  • iterator begin();
  • iterator end();
  • iterator find(T1 first);
  • tBSTNode<T1, T2>* GetInorderSuccessor(tBSTNode<T1, T2>* _node);
  • tBSTNode<T1, T2>* GetInorderPredecessor(tBSTNode<T1, T2>* _node);
  • bool insert(const tPair<T1, T2>& _pair);
  • iterator erase(const iterator& itr);
  • tBSTNode<T1, T2>* deleteNode(tBSTNode<T1, T2>* _node);

These are the functions that we focused on. These functions cover up the major parts of functionalities

template<typename T1, typename T2>
inline typename cBST<T1, T2>::iterator cBST<T1, T2>::begin()
{
	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* node = this->rootBSTNode;

	while (nullptr != node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD]) {
		node = node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD];
	}

	return iterator(this, node);
}

template<typename T1, typename T2>
inline typename cBST<T1, T2>::iterator cBST<T1, T2>::end()
{
	return iterator(this, nullptr);
}

template<typename T1, typename T2>
inline typename cBST<T1, T2>::iterator cBST<T1, T2>::find(T1 first)
{
 	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* target = this->rootBSTNode;

	if (this->rootBSTNode == nullptr)
	{
		return cBST<T1, T2>::end();
	}
	else
	{
		NodeType nodeType = NodeType::END;

		while (target != nullptr)
		{
			// using enum class first determine where to put it
			if (first < target->pair.first) {
				nodeType = NodeType::LCHILD;
			}
			else if (first > target->pair.first) {
				nodeType = NodeType::RCHILD;
			}
			else {
				break;
			}
			// code from video was confusing so cleaned it upp myself
			target = target->arrNode[(int)nodeType];
		}
	}
	return iterator(this, target);
}

As always, basic implementation for begin() and end(). find() is also easy, just compare and move on until we reach our target.

template<typename T1, typename T2>
inline bool cBST<T1, T2>::insert(const tPair<T1, T2>& _pair)
{
	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* node = new tBSTNode<T1, T2>(_pair);

	if (this->rootBSTNode == nullptr)
	{
		this->rootBSTNode = node;
	}
	else
	{
		tBSTNode<T1, T2>* target = this->rootBSTNode;
		NodeType nodeType = NodeType::END;

		while (true)
		{
			// using enum class first determine where to put it
			if (node->pair.first < target->pair.first) {
				nodeType = NodeType::LCHILD;
			}
			else if (node->pair.first > target->pair.first){
				nodeType = NodeType::RCHILD;
			}
			else {
				return false;	// for now we will discard any duplicate value
			}

			// actually put the damn thing 
			if (target->arrNode[(int)nodeType] == nullptr) {
				target->arrNode[(int)nodeType] = node;
				node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT] = target;
				break;
			}
			else {
				target = target->arrNode[(int)nodeType];
			}
		}

	}

	this->iCount++;
	return true;
}

insert() shared the same structure as find(); Go in, compare node, insert said node. Note that we recieve tPair as input, so we make our node inside the function using that tPair. Every other parts of the code is simple enough to just read through.

template<typename T1, typename T2>
inline tBSTNode<T1, T2>* cBST<T1, T2>::GetInorderSuccessor(tBSTNode<T1, T2>* _node) {
	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* pSuccessor = nullptr;

	// see right node	-> if exists go to that right node
	//					-> go down until leftLeafChild
	if (_node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::RCHILD] != nullptr)
	{
		pSuccessor = _node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::RCHILD];
		while (pSuccessor->arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD])
		{
			pSuccessor = pSuccessor->arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD];
		}
	}
	else
	{
		// if leaf node
		//	-> go to parent 
		//	-> go up until current parent is leftChild of it's parent( aka PP )
		//	-> that "PP" is the answer
		pSuccessor = _node;
		while (true) {
			if (pSuccessor->isRoot()) {
				// if came this far that means that you only have 1 item and thats root
				return nullptr;
			}
			// this "if" block is used for both situation when "_node" is L & R 
			if (pSuccessor->isLeft()) {
				pSuccessor = pSuccessor->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT];
				break;
			}
			else {
				pSuccessor = pSuccessor->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT];
			}
		}
	}
	return pSuccessor;
}

template<typename T1, typename T2>
inline tBSTNode<T1, T2>* cBST<T1, T2>::GetInorderPredecessor(tBSTNode<T1, T2>* _node)
{
	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* pSuccessor = nullptr;

	// see left node	-> if exists go to that right node
	//					-> go down until leftLeafChild
	if (_node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD] != nullptr)
	{
		pSuccessor = _node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD];
		while (pSuccessor->arrNode[(int)NodeType::RCHILD])
		{
			pSuccessor = pSuccessor->arrNode[(int)NodeType::RCHILD];
		}
	}
	else
	{
		// if leaf node
		//	-> go to parent 
		//	-> go up until current parent is leftChild of it's parent( aka PP )
		//	-> that "PP" is the answer
		while (true) {
			pSuccessor = _node;
			if (pSuccessor->isRoot()) {
				// if came this far that means that you only have 1 item and thats root
				return nullptr;
			}
			// this "if" block is used for both situation when "_pair" is L & R 
			if (pSuccessor->isRight()) {
				pSuccessor = pSuccessor->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT];
				break;
			}
			else {
				pSuccessor = pSuccessor->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT];
			}
		}
	}
	return pSuccessor;
}

Now these two functions can be tricky but still pretty obvious once we understand how things work. As the name suggest we get our successor or predecessor based on the given node ininorder. Inorder first starts from the left node, go up to parent node then goes down to right node. This pattern is applied during the whole traversal. So if the given node is a left node, the successor should be its’ parent node, and for parent node it should be its’ right node. right node should go to the next left node.

To sum up the pattern (GetInorderSuccessor for now) above it boils down to …

  • If the given node has right node child, go there and jump down its’ left node child until that child node is a leaf node.

  • If the given node is a root node, we just return nullptr. This is because we already check for its’ right node child and we know its empty, so no successor for that node.(TLDR the tree has one root node or root + leftChild)

  • If the given node is a leaf node, we loop through the process of stepping up its’ parent node. Now if the leaf node is considered left node we step up once and just return that parent. If considered right node, we keep looping.

The actaul code uses this pattern (with proper ordering logic ofcourse) to achieve inorder traversal.

template<typename T1, typename T2>
inline typename cBST<T1, T2>::iterator cBST<T1, T2>::erase(const iterator& itr) {
	assert(itr.bst == this);	// had to add cBST as friend class inside iterator

	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* pSuccessor = deleteNode(itr.node);

	--this->iCount;
	return iterator(this, pSuccessor);

}

template <typename T1, typename T2>
inline tBSTNode<T1, T2>* cBST<T1, T2>::deleteNode(tBSTNode<T1, T2>* _node) {
// when dealing with erasing elements inside bst,
// we need to catagorize it by cases
// 1. when there are no child for that node(aka leafNode)
// 2. when there are one child for that node
// 3. when there are two child for that node

// (1) is simple. just earse that node. 
// (2) is also simple. just copy the value that child node 
//	had to the target and erase the child
// (3) needs little thinking. The child is actually not the problem in this case.
// what we need to think about is the order we look the tree with(currently inorder).
// so its actually either a Successor or Predecessor of target node that gets replaced with the target.
// These two nodes are guaranteed to have one or less child by design so no need to worry about (3) repeating itself.

	tBSTNode<T1, T2>* pNode = GetInorderSuccessor(_node);

	// (1)
	if (_node->isLeaf()) {

		if (_node->isRoot()) {
			this->rootBSTNode = nullptr;
		}
		else
		{
			// go to parent -> see which child was this -> block that pointer -> finally delete child
			if (_node->isLeft()) {
				_node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT]->arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD] = nullptr;
			}
			else {
				_node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT]->arrNode[(int)NodeType::RCHILD] = nullptr;
			}
		}
		delete _node;
	}
	else if (_node->isFull()) {
		// (3) -> targets' successor is the actual "node" thats getting deleted
		//	but the value it self gets transfered 
		_node->pair = pNode->pair;
		deleteNode(pNode);	// to deal with either this having 1 child or none
		pNode = _node;
	}
	else {
		// (2) 100% only has 1 child  
		NodeType targetChildType = NodeType::LCHILD;
		if (_node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::RCHILD])
			targetChildType = NodeType::RCHILD;

		// if target == root
		if (_node->isRoot()) {
			// child that is left becomes root
			this->rootBSTNode = _node->arrNode[(int)targetChildType];
			_node->arrNode[(int)targetChildType]->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT] = nullptr;
		}
		else
		{
			// now we need to know target node is left || right child
			if (_node->isLeft()) {
				_node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT]->arrNode[(int)NodeType::LCHILD] = _node->arrNode[(int)targetChildType];
			}
			else {
				_node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT]->arrNode[(int)NodeType::RCHILD] = _node->arrNode[(int)targetChildType];
			}
			_node->arrNode[(int)targetChildType]->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT] = _node->arrNode[(int)NodeType::PARENT];
		}

		delete _node;
	}

	return pNode;
}

deleteNode() is defined as private function and is only used inside earse() function (design purpose i guess). Im getting lazy right now and don’t want to write obvious explaination of code and i commented parts that i felt i missed so yeah… i guess this is it.

// <inside main.cpp>
// to test erase
	
	//	[Creating the following tree]
	//				100	
	//		50				150
	//	25		75		125		175
	cBST<int, wchar_t> myBST;
	myBST.insert(make_tPair(100, L'ㄱ'));	
	myBST.insert(make_tPair(150, L'ㄴ'));	
	myBST.insert(make_tPair(50, L'ㄷ'));	
	myBST.insert(make_tPair(25, L'ㄹ'));
	myBST.insert(make_tPair(75, L'ㅁ'));
	myBST.insert(make_tPair(125, L'ㅂ'));
	myBST.insert(make_tPair(175, L'ㅅ'));
	
	cBST<int, wchar_t>::iterator myItr = myBST.begin();
	/*
	myItr = myBST.find(25);
	myItr = myBST.erase(myItr);	// will return what it got replaced with (this case 175)

	myItr = myBST.find(75);
	myItr = myBST.erase(myItr);	
	*/ 
	myItr = myBST.find(100);
	myItr = myBST.erase(myItr);

This is the part (inside main.cpp) that i tested the bst class. It works no problem.

End

item.title: [AssortRock_2021_C++_Course] List Iteratory
item.author: ljheric7@gmail.com (Eric Lim)
item.description:
Basic C/C++

유튜브 무료강의 플레이리스트인 “C언어/C++ 무료강의 [2021년 특강]“의 영상을 통해 배운 내용 정리

List Iterator

이전 darray와 마찬가지로 inner class로 iterator를 만들고 그 안에 friend로 List가 접급할 수 있도록 만든다.

기본적으로 작동하는 방식만 List의 특성에 맞게 바꿔준다. iterator를 사용한 insert()와 erase()의 경우 std::list가 사용하는 방식을 따라하도록 만든다.

왠만하면 주석으로 적어놨다

...
// inside CList<T> class
	class iterator
	{
	private:
		CList<T>* list;
		tListNode<T>* item;
		bool isValid;

	public:
		// 해당 값을 받고 그 값을 수정도 할 수 있어야 되기 때문에
		// 레퍼런스로 받는다.
		T& operator*()
		{
			return item->data;
		}

		bool operator==(const iterator& _other)
		{
			if (list == _other.list && item == _other.item)
			{
				return true;
			}
			return false;
		}
		bool operator!=(const iterator& _other)
		{
			return !(*this == _other);
		}

		iterator& operator++()
		{
			// end 인경우 라던가 제외
			if (!isValid || list == nullptr)
				assert(nullptr);
			// 다음으로 넘어가는데 만약 내가 마지막이였으면 넘어가면서 nullptr
			// 즉 end 값이 된다
			item = item->pNext;
			return *this;
		}
		iterator operator++(int)
		{
			// construct temp iterator
			iterator tempIter(list, item);
			++(*this);
			return tempIter;
		}
 
		iterator& operator --()
		{
			// end 인경우 라던가 제외
			if (!isValid || list == nullptr)
				assert(nullptr);
			// 다음으로 넘어가는데 만약 내가 마지막이였으면 넘어가면서 nullptr
			// 즉 end 값이 된다
			item = item->pPrev;
			return *this;
		}

		iterator operator --(int)
		{
			// construct temp iterator
			iterator tempIter(list, item);
			--(*this);
			return tempIter;
		}


	public:
		iterator()
			: list(nullptr)
			, item(nullptr)
			, isValid(false) {}

		iterator(CList<T>* _list, tListNode<T>* _item)
			: list(_list)
			, item(_item)
			, isValid(false)
		{
			// 더 상세한 구분이 있어야되지만 일단 패스
			if (_list != nullptr && _item != nullptr) 
			{
				isValid = true;
			}
		}
		// 가르키기만 하는 놈이 지워질때 뭔가 할 필요 X
		~iterator() {}

		friend CList;
	};
//
...

// 함수 구현
// typename CArr<T>::iterator 
// typename to show "CArr<T>::iterator" is a type (bc its inner class)
template <typename T>
inline typename CList<T>::iterator CList<T>::begin() {
	if (m_pHead == nullptr)
		return end();
	return iterator(this, this->m_pHead);
}

template <typename T>
inline typename CList<T>::iterator CList<T>::end()
{
	return iterator(this, nullptr);
}

/*
    CList<T> 안에 정의되어있음
	iterator insert(const iterator& _iter, const T& _data);
	iterator erase(iterator& _iter);
*/

template<typename T>
inline typename CList<T>::iterator CList<T>::insert(const iterator& _iter, const T& _data)
{
	// 에초에 걸러야되는 조건들
	// @@ if (_iter == end()) @@ : this conversion is not allowed
	if (end() == _iter)
	{
		assert(nullptr);
	}

	// 1. 넣을 리스트 노드 동적할당 받기
	tListNode<T>* pNode = new tListNode<T>(_data, nullptr, nullptr);

	// 2. std::list와 마찬가지로 iter의 앞으로 넣기
	if (_iter.item == m_pHead)
	{
		// 단 만약 iter.item이 헤드인 경우는 다르게 처리
		// 이경우 들어온 값이 헤드가 된다.
		_iter.item->pPrev = pNode;
		pNode->pNext = _iter.item;
		pNode->pPrev = pNode;

		m_pHead = pNode;
	}
	else
	{
		// 새로 들어온 값을 연결
		pNode->pPrev = _iter.item->pPrev;
		pNode->pNext = _iter.item;
		// 기존 값들의 경로를 새로 들어온 값으로 변경
		_iter.item->pPrev->pNext = pNode;
		_iter.item->pPrev = pNode;
	}

	// 갯수 증가
	++m_iCount;

	// std::list와 같이 되돌려주는 iter는 삽입된 놈을 반환
	// this == _iter.list
	return iterator(this, pNode);
}

template<typename T>
inline typename CList<T>::iterator CList<T>::erase(iterator& _iter)
{
	// 목표 : 지운 자리로 들어오는 앞에 놈에 관한 iterator 반환

	// end인 경우 오류
	if (end() == _iter)
	{
		assert(nullptr);
	}

	// insert와 마찬가지로 처음과 처음이 아닌 경우로 나눈다
	if (m_pHead == _iter.item)
	{
		// Head 앞에 값의 pPrev를 자기자신으로 변경
		_iter.item->pNext->pPrev = _iter.item->pNext;
		// head update
		m_pHead = _iter.item->pNext;
	}
	else
	{
		_iter.item->pPrev->pNext = _iter.item->pNext;
		_iter.item->pNext->pPrev = _iter.item->pPrev;
	}
	// save the next item address to return
	tListNode<T>* erasedResult = _iter.item->pNext;
	// no longer valid + erase from memory
	_iter.isValid = false;
	delete _iter.item;
	
	return iterator(this, erasedResult);
}

inline

Visual Studio를 통해서 자동완성으로 클래스 함수(템플릿)를 헤더에 정의할려고 하면 inline키워드가 앞에 사용된다. 이 키워드는 함수의 내용을 불린 부분에 복붙을 한다(약간 #include가 하는 일이랑 비슷하다고 생각한다). 자세한 설명은 책리뷰에 Game Engine Architecture 챕터3에 적었다.

몰랐던 내용이라고 한다면 클래스의 함수를 헤더안에서 작성한 경우 키워드의 유무와 관계없이 inline 처리 된다고 한다. 그 이유가 One Definition Rule (ODR) 때문이라고 한다.

The One Definition Rule (ODR) is an important rule of the C++ programming language that prescribes that classes/structs and non-inline functions cannot have more than one definition in the entire program and template and types cannot have more than one definition by translation unit. It is defined in the ISO C++ Standard (ISO/IEC 14882) 2003, at section 3.2.
위키피디아

클래스의 멤버함수가 헤더안에 정의되었다면 해당 헤더파일을 참조하는 모든 이들이 그 복사본을 갖게 되기 때문에 인라인화를 디폴트로 시킨다고 한다.

inline을 한다고 무조건 코드내용이 복붙되는건 아니다. 이는 컴파일러의 재량이므로 해당 키워드를 사용한다면 컴파일러에게 “왠만하면 해주세요” 의 느낌이 더 크다고 한다.

End

[Reference]
아소트락 2021 C/C++ 강의

item.title: [AssortRock_2021_C++_Course] erase(...) Dynamic Array
item.author: ljheric7@gmail.com (Eric Lim)
item.description:
Basic C/C++

유튜브 무료강의 플레이리스트인 “C언어/C++ 무료강의 [2021년 특강]“의 영상을 통해 배운 내용 정리”

erase()

#include <vector>
#include <list>

using std::vector;
using std::list;

int main(int argc, char** argv){
	std::vector<int> vec;
	vec.push_back(100);
	vec.push_back(200);
	vec.push_back(300);
	
	std::vector<int>::iterator vecitr = vec.begin();
	vec.erase(vecitr);
	// vecitr = vec.erase(vecitr); 이렇게 했으면 에러 아님

	int i = *vecitr;	// ERROR

	std::vector<int>::iterator vecitr = vec.begin();
	int inum = *vecitr;	// OKOK reads "200"
 


	reutrn 0;
}

std::vector의 erase()함수의 사용 예시다. 지우고 나서 int i로 값을 받는 순간 에러처리가 된다. 근데 디버거로 그당시 vecitr값을 보면 200을 가르키고 있다. 당연하지만 200이라는 값이 보이는 이유는 가변배열의 특성상 당연히 값이 앞으로 옮겨지니깐 그런거다. std::vector입장에서는 vecitr가 가르키고 있던 정보는 사라져서 지금 이상한 값을(비록 맞는 값이지만) 가르키고 있기 때문에 틀린 변수라고 인식하는 거다.
erase()의 반환값을 보면 iterator를 반환한다. 위에서 말한 앞당겨진 값을 가르키는 iterator를 반환해서 기존에 가르키던 iterator를 최신화하는 방식이다.

이제 만들어보자.


// inside class CArr<T>
...
iterator erase(const iterator& _other)
...

...
template<typename T>
inline CArr<T>::iterator CArr<T>::erase(const iterator& _other)
{

	return iterator();
}

iterator가 가르키고 있는 부분을 지워야된다. 이 함수가 있는 CArr가 iterator가 가르키는 곳을 참조하여 지워야되는데 정보를 다 private으로 저장하고 있어서 힘들다. iterator에서 해당 값들을 제공하는 Getter()함수를 만들어도 되지만 여기서는 friend 키워드를 통해 문제를 해결한다. 원래 내부클래스인 iterator만 CArr의 private멤버변수에 접근하고 그 반대는 안됬다. 만약 iterator클래스 안에서 friend CArr;를 선언해주면 CArr에서 iterator의 private에 접근가능하다는 내용이다. 헷갈리면 안된다. A가 B를 친구로 멋대로 선언하고 들어가서 가져오는 것 보다 A가 B를 친구라고 인정하고 B가 A의 변수들을 가져오는게 예의(?)에 맞다.

...
// inside iterator
	class iterator // inner class can access upper class private member 
	{
	private:
		//long long m_i;	// 8byte : this does not eat up 8bytes, 
						// this part is just declaring. iterator and CArr is different class,
						// its just that iterator is inside CArr; so we can call iterator from "CArr::"
		CArr* m_pArr;
		T* m_pData;
		int m_iIdx;		// -1인 경우를 end 라고 정함 (임의로)
		bool isValid;	// when erased or smth 

	public:
	...
	...
		iterator() :
			m_pArr(nullptr),
			m_pData(nullptr),
			m_iIdx(-1),
			isValid(false)
		{
		}
		iterator(CArr* _pArr, T* _pData, int _idx) :
			m_pArr(_pArr),
			m_pData(_pData),
			m_iIdx(_idx),
			isValid(false)
		{
			if (m_pArr != nullptr && 0 <= _idx)
			{
				isValid = true;
			}
		}
	}
...

template<typename T>
typename CArr<T>::iterator CArr<T>::erase(iterator& _other)
{
	// this == _other.m_pArr;

	// check if iterator that we got is even valid
	// 1. EOF | 2. pointing other CArr 
	if (this != _other.m_pArr || end() == _other || m_iCount <= _other.m_iIdx)
	{
		assert(nullptr);
	}
	// pull the next item upfront
	int iLoopidx = m_iCount - (_other.m_iIdx + 1);
	for (int idx = 0; idx < iLoopidx; ++idx)
	{
		m_pData[_other.m_iIdx + idx] = m_pData[_other.m_iIdx + idx + 1];
	}
	// decrease count
	--m_iCount;
	// this will make it so that the original iterator
	// still points to the right number but still not valid 
	// -> same as std::vector<T>.erase()
	_other.isValid = false; 
	return iterator(this, m_pData, _other.m_iIdx);
}

딱히 신기한거 없다. std::vector의 earse()처럼 기존 iterator를 정상취급 안하게 isValid으로 설정한다. “왜 이런식으로 만드냐?“는 iterator가 사용되는 모든 컨테이너에 동일한 규칙을 갖는 인터페이스 형태이기 때문이다 (근데 C++17부터 std::iterator deprecated 당했다고 한다…).

좀 재밌는 내용이 마지막에 나온다.


// std::vector<int> vec = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8}
// std::vector<int>::iterator vecitr = vec.begin()

// delete 1 ~ 5
for (;vecitr != vec.end(); ++vecitr)
{
	if (*vecitr >= 1 && *vecitr <= 5)
	{
		vecitr = vec.erase(vecitr);
	}
}

// result : 2,4,6,7,8

결과가 틀리게 나온다. 당연한게 erase() 때문에 앞당겨지고 다시 for loop때문에 한번 더 앞당겨지니깐 지울때마다 효과적으로 2번 점프하는 효과가 있는거다.

for (;vecitr != vec.end();)
{
	if (*vecitr >= 1 && *vecitr <= 5)
	{
		vecitr = vec.erase(vecitr);
	}
	else
	{
		 ++vecitr;
	}
}

이러면 안지울때만 점프하도록 바꾸는거다. 이럼 문제해결.

End

[Reference]
아소트락 2021 C/C++ 강의

item.title: [AssortRock_2021_C++_Course] Iterator
item.author: ljheric7@gmail.com (Eric Lim)
item.description:
Basic C/C++

유튜브 무료강의 플레이리스트인 “C언어/C++ 무료강의 [2021년 특강]“의 영상을 통해 배운 내용 정리

Iterator

#include <vector>
#include <list>

using std::vector;
using std::list;

int main(int argc, char** argv){
	
	vector<int> vecInt;
	list<int> listInt;

	vecInt.push_back(10);
	vecInt.push_back(20);
	vecInt.push_back(30);
	vecInt.push_back(40);
	vecInt.push_back(50);

	for(size_t i = 0; i < vecInt.size(); ++i){
		printf("%d ", vecInt[i]);
	}

	listInt.push_back(10);
	listInt.push_back(20);
	listInt.push_back(30);
	listInt.push_back(40);
	listInt.push_back(50);
	listInt.push_back(60);

	// Wrong !! <list> does not have "[]" operator : bc not continuous inside memory
	/*
	for(size_t j = 0; j < listInt.size(); ++j){
		printf("%d ", listInt[i]);
	}
	*/
	reutrn 0;
}

이전에 만든 Dynamic Array나 Linked List는 이미 존재함. 구현방법에 의해 list의 경우 []오퍼레이터를 사용불가. 같은 효과를 내기 위해 iterator가
구현됨


	std::list<int> listInt;
	listInt.push_back(1);
	listInt.push_back(2);
	listInt.push_back(3);

	std::list<int>::iterator itr = listInt.begin();
	int iData1 = *itr;	// iData1 == 1
	++itr;
	iData1 = *itr;	// iData1 == 2;


	vector<int> vecInt;
	list<int> listInt;

	vecInt.push_back(10);
	vecInt.push_back(20);
	vecInt.push_back(30);
	
	std::vector<int>::iterator itr = vecInt.begin();
	int iData2 = *itr;	// iData2 == 10

iterator는 클래스 안에 클래스, 즉 inner class로 구현되어 있다. 해당 객체 안에 앞, 혹은 뒤를 나타낼 수 있는 begin()이나 end()를 입력할 수 있다. end()의 경우 가르키는 값은 마지막 데이터보다 한칸 뒤를 가르킨다. 그래서 for루프와 같은 형식에서 조건으로 사용해도 마지막 값이 참조가 안되는 일은 없다. 값을 받아올 때 포인터와 같은 표현을 쓰는데 이건 Operatio Overload에 의한 것이다. vector 또한 iterator가 구현되어있다. 벡터의 경우 필요없어보이지만 사용처가 없는건 아니다. vector의 함수 중에 erase()를 보면 인자로 삭제할 값을 iterator로 받는다. 이러한 설계는 여러 컨테이너에도 적용되어 있다.

iterator는 산수연산을 통해 다음 혹은 이전 값으로 이동할 수 있다.

우리가 만든 리스트와 벡터에 해당 기능을 만들어보자. iterator는 시작 주소값과 해당 데이터의 인덱스 값을 알고 있어야된다.

class iterator 
	{
	private:
		T* m_pData;
		int m_iIdx;

	public:
		iterator() :
			m_pData(nullptr),
			m_iIdx(-1)
		{
		}

		iterator(T* _pData, int _idx):
			m_pData(_pData),
			m_iIdx(_idx)
		{
		}

		~iterator() {
		}
	};

참고로 만들어졌다고 해서 상위 클래스인 CArr의 크기가 늘어나진 않는다. 어디까지나 타입을 명시하는 것이기 때문이다.

이제 필요한 함수들을 만들면 된다. 우선 begin()함수다. 기존의 컨테이너가 해당 함수를 호출할 때 iterator가 아닌 컨테이너 자신에서부터 호출하는 것을 알 수 있다. 또한 반환값은 iterator가 받기 때문에 해당 함수의 반환값은 iterator가 된다.



template <typename T>
class CArr
{
private:
	T*		m_pData;		// 8byte
	int		m_iCount;		// 4byte
	int		m_iMaxCount;	// 4byte

public:
	...
	iterator begin();

public:
	class iterator{
		...
	};
};

...

template <typename T>
typename CArr<T>::iterator CArr<T>::begin() {
	// 시작을 가르키는 iterator를 반환해줘야됨 
	return iterator(m_pData, 0);
}

구현부를 보면 반환타입을 typename CArr<T>::iterator라고 해놨다. 이건 iterator가 inner class이기 때문에 확실하게 속성이라고 명시하기 위해 적는다.

앞으로 필요한 연산은 참조연산자 *, 증감 연산자 전/후, 비교 연산자 가 있다.

operator *

우선 몇가지 수정사항.

// typename CArr<T>::iterator 
// typename to show "CArr<T>::iterator" is a type
template <typename T>
typename CArr<T>::iterator CArr<T>::begin() {
	if (0 == m_iCount)
		return iterator(this, m_pData, -1);
	// 시작을 가르키는 iterator를 반환해줘야됨 
	return iterator(this, m_pData, 0);
}

template <typename T>
typename CArr<T>::iterator CArr<T>::end()
{
	return iterator(this, m_pData, -1);
}

임의로 -1을 end값으로 정함. begin()의 경우 아무것도 없는 경우 end()와 같은 결과를 리턴하도록 설정. 생성자도 처음에 아무 입력값 없는 경우 m_iIdx(-1)로 설정.

class iterator // inner class can access upper class private member 
	{
	private:
		//long long m_i;	// 8byte : this does not eat up 8bytes, 
						// this part is just declaring. iterator and CArr is different class,
						// its just that iterator is inside CArr; so we can call iterator from "CArr::"
		CArr* m_pArr;
		T* m_pData;
		int m_iIdx;	// -1인 경우를 end 라고 정함 (임의로)
		...
	}

CArr*를 멤버변수로 갖는다. resize()가 계속 발생한면 원래 주소가 아닌 다른 공간으로 변하는데 기존 주소를 찍고 있는 iterator의 경우 이를 참조할려고 하면 당연히 문제가 생긴다. 이를 방지하기 위해 CArr*를 갖고 있다가 참조할 때마다 확인한다.

	T& operator *()
	{
		// 늘리는 도중 주소가 달라진 경우를 체크
		if (m_pArr->m_pData != m_pData || -1 == m_iIdx)
			assert(nullptr);
		return m_pData[m_iIdx];
	}

접근연산자다. 딱히 놀라운 부분은 없다.

operator ++ / –

	iterator& operator ++()
	{
		// ++(++k) 같은걸 할 수 있어야됨 -> 즉 자기자신이 돌아와야됨
		return *this;
	}
	iterator& operator --()
	{
		// ++(++k) 같은걸 할 수 있어야됨 -> 즉 자기자신이 돌아와야됨
		return *this;
	}

일단 구조는 이렇다.

	iterator& operator ++()
	{	
		// end인경우 || 원본주소가 변경된 경우
		if (m_iIdx == -1 || m_pArr->m_pData != m_pData)
			assert(nullptr);
		// 마지막인 경우  => 딱히 오류사항은 아님
		if (m_iIdx + 1 == m_pArr->m_iCount)
		{
			m_iIdx = -1;	// 마지막을 가르키게 세팅
		}
		else
		{
			++m_iIdx;
		}
		// ++(++k) 같은걸 할 수 있어야됨 -> 즉 자기자신이 돌아와야됨
		return *this;
	}

후위연산자 구현이다. 예외처리 해주고 반환하면 된다. 반환은 위에서 만든 operator*()를 사용한다. 딱히 놀라운 부분은 없다.

	CArr<int> carr;
	carr.push_back(1);
	carr.push_back(2);
	carr.push_back(3);
	
	CArr<int>::iterator myItr = carr.begin();
	// 비교연산자도 만들어야된다
	for (; myItr != carr.end(); ++myItr)
	{
		std::cout << *myItr << std::endl;
	}

다만 실제 사용을 할려고 하면 비교연산자가 없다고 난리친다.

	bool operator ==(const iterator& _other)
	{
		// 당연하지만 idx만 같으면 안됨 
		return (this->m_pData == _other.m_pData) && (this->m_iIdx == _other.m_iIdx);
	}
	bool operator !=(const iterator& _other)
	{ 
		return !(*this == _other);
	}

비교연산자다. 밑에 부분은 기존에꺼 뜯어 쓰는게 좀 재밌었다.

이제 전위 연산자 만들면 된다 (어차피 --의 경우 지금 하는 연산 반대로 하면 된다). 전위의 경우 동작방식을 조금 다르게 만들어야된다. 함수호출은 바로 되는데 실질적인 연산결과의 경우 바로 나오지 않는다. 호출한 라인에서는 변화가 없다가 그다음 라인부터 효과가 있다. 위에서 했던 iterator&를 반환타입으로 하면 자신에게 수행한 연산결과가 바로 반환되기 때문에 iterator로 반환해준다. 자신의 복사본을 반환하고 연산은 그대로 수행하는 트릭이다.

		iterator operator ++(int)
		{
			// 참고로 기본 대입연산자의 경우 만들어지는 디폴트를 쓰고있음
			iterator temp = *this;	// (복사) -> 나중에 스코프 밖으로 나가면 삭제

 			// end인경우 || 원본주소가 변경된 경우
			if (m_iIdx == -1 || m_pArr->m_pData != m_pData)
				assert(nullptr);

			// 마지막인 경우  => 딱히 오류사항은 아님
			if (m_iIdx + 1 == m_pArr->m_iCount)
			{
				m_iIdx = -1;	// 마지막을 가르키게 세팅
			}
			else
			{
				++m_iIdx;
			}

			return temp;	// (임시저장소에서) 리턴되는 곳에서 복사되고 다시 삭제된다.
		}

인자를 int를 주면 이걸 후위연산자라고 알아먹는다.

	myItr = carr.begin();
	std::cout << *(myItr++) << std::endl;
	std::cout << *myItr << std::endl;

이러면 자연스럽게 (뒤에서 증가를 안해도) 첫번째와 두번째 값이 나온다.

반환타입을 보면 알 수 있듯이 후위는 복사가 없다. 만약 전위연산을 실행하는 값이 기본 데이터타입이 아니라 훨씬 큰크기를 갖는 무언가라면 복사비용이 생긴다.

operator--() 관련 부분이다. 기존 STL에 들어있는 벡터랑 리스트의 경우 begin 이든 end던 --는 에러처리더라.

iterator& operator --()
		{
			// begin 인경우 || 원본주소가 변경된 경우 || end인 경우
			if (m_iIdx == 0 || m_pArr->m_pData != m_pData || m_iIdx == -1)
				assert(nullptr);

			--m_iIdx;

			// --(--k) 같은걸 할 수 있어야됨 -> 즉 자기자신이 돌아와야됨
			return *this;
		}

		iterator operator --(int)
		{
			iterator temp = *this;

			// begin 인경우 || 원본주소가 변경된 경우 || end인 경우
			if (m_iIdx == 0 || m_pArr->m_pData != m_pData || m_iIdx == -1)
				assert(nullptr);

			--m_iIdx;

			return temp;
		}

End

[Reference]
아소트락 2021 C/C++ 강의

item.title: [AssortRock_2021_C++_Course] Namespace & cout / cin
item.author: ljheric7@gmail.com (Eric Lim)
item.description:
Basic C/C++

유튜브 무료강의 플레이리스트인 “C언어/C++ 무료강의 [2021년 특강]“의 영상을 통해 배운 내용 정리

Namespace

Namespace를 통해 작성한 코드를 하나의 그룹으로 묶어둘 수 있다.

namespace foo{
	int add(int a, int b){
		return a + b;
	}
}

int add(){
	printf("Add");
}

int main(){
	add();
	foo::add(1,2);
}

애초에 계속 사용할 namespace의 경우 using namespace 이름 를 통해 해당 translation에서 명칭 표기 없이 사용할 수 있다.

std::cout & std::cin

입출력을 위한 함수다. 모두 #include <iostream>으로 이용할 수 있다.

int main(void){
	int iNum = 10;
	std::cin >> iNum;
	std::cout << "hello " << 10 << " int : " << iNum << std::endl;
	return 0;
}

std::cin으로 입력을 받을 수 있다. std::cout으로 스트림으로 연결되는 데이터를 그대로 output으로 출력한다. 둘다 모두 std namespace에서 나온다. 이 외에도 여러 기능들이 std에 포함되어있기 때문에 나중에 자신이 만든 기능과 명칭이 겹쳐질 수 있기 때문에 using namespace std;는 권장하지 않는다. 정 사용하고 싶다면 특정 기능을 한번에 쓰면 된다.

using namespace std::cout;
using namespace std::cin;
using namespace std::endl;

int main(void){
	int iNum = 0;
	cin >> iNum;
	cout << "Using Namespace std::cout : " << iNum << endl;
	return 0;
}

2바이트 문자열을 출력하기 위한 wcout & wcin 존재함

why do cout & cin work like this

std::cout은 ostream이라는 객체고 std::cin은 istream이라는 객체다. 둘다 extern으로 지정된 전역변수다. 둘다 사용하는 <<나 >>는 기존 비트쉬프트 연산을 연산자 Overloading한 형태이다.

class myClass{
	
public:
	myClass& operator << (const wchar_t* _data){
		printf("%s ", _data);
		return *this;
	}

};

class myClass_in{	
public:
	// 대상에 삽입하고 싶다 == 레퍼런스 인자
	myClass& operator >> (int& _data){
		scanf_s("%d", &_data);	// 레퍼런스의 주소 == 원본변수 주소
		return *this;
	}
};

int main(){
	std::cout << << << << <<.....
	// 연속적으로 자기자신을 부른다

	// 지역 설정
	setlocale(LC_ALL, "korean");
	_wsetlocale(LC_ALL, L"korean");

	myClass mycout;
	mycout << L"안녕" << L"안녕";

	int iNum = 0;
	myClass_in mycin;
	mycin >> iNum;



	return 0;
}

[결과화면]
안녕 안녕

std::endl

std::endl은 한줄 내려가는 함수다. 받아쓰기 위해 함수 포인터로 받으면 사용에 문제 없다. 물론 기능이 \n만 있는건 아니다.


class myClass{
	
public:

	myClass& operator << (const char* _data){
		printf("%s ", _data);
		return *this;
	}

	myClass& operator << (const wchar_t* _data){
		printf("%s ", _data);
		return *this;
	}

	myClass& operator << (void(*pfunc)(void)){
		pfunc();
		return *this;
	}
};

int main(){
	myClass myCout;
	myCout << 10 << "hakko" << L"안녕" << std::endl;


	return 0;
}

End

[Reference]
아소트락 2021 C/C++ 강의

item.title: [AssortRock_2021_C++_Course] Small Project : DArray Using Class
item.author: ljheric7@gmail.com (Eric Lim)
item.description:
Basic C/C++

유튜브 무료강의 플레이리스트인 “C언어/C++ 무료강의 [2021년 특강]“의 영상을 통해 배운 내용 정리

Dynamic Array

We will make our Dynamic Array form Dynamic Allocation chapter using class.

Basic Class Layout

CArr.h

#pragma once
class CArr
{
private:
	int*	m_pInt;
	int		m_iCount;
	int		m_iMaxCount;

public:
	void push_back(int _Data);
	void resize(int _iResizeCount);

	//int* operator[] (int idx);
	int& operator[] (int idx);


public:
	CArr();
	~CArr();
};

This is the basic class format that we are going to use as our DArray. Unlike the struct counterpart, we made variables private so that its safe inside our class and needs extra work to access these data; using member functions. Implementation of said member functions are inside CArr.cpp.

CArr.cpp

#include "CArr.h"
#include <assert.h>
CArr::CArr()
	: 
	m_pInt(nullptr)
	, m_iCount(0)
	, m_iMaxCount(2) 
{
	m_pInt = new int[2];
}

CArr::~CArr() 
{
	delete[] m_pInt;
}

First we have our constructor and destructor. When we implement class member functions outside class body, we tell the compiler where this function comes form by adding ClassName:: at the front of the function name. Functions themselves are self explanatory; We Allocate needed memory for our array and free allocated memory once we don’t need it.

void CArr::push_back(int _Data)
{
	if (m_iCount >= m_iMaxCount) 
	{
		// expand space
		resize(m_iMaxCount * 2);
	}
	// data input
	m_pInt[m_iCount++] = _Data;
}

push_back() function didn’t change that much either. Variables changed to use member variable unlike struct implementation. The input parameter for Reallocate(), which is resize() for class edition, has changed to directly insert the desired size.

void CArr::resize(int _iResizeCount)
{
	// This situation doesn't make sense at all
	if (m_iMaxCount >= _iResizeCount) {
		assert(nullptr);
	}

	// 1. reallocate for more space : reallocate as much as input
	int* pNew = new int[_iResizeCount];

	// 2. copy original data to newly aquired Darr
	for (int i = 0; i < m_iCount; ++i) {
		pNew[i] = m_pInt[i];
	}

	// 3. free original Darr & point towards new Darr
	delete[] m_pInt;
	m_pInt = pNew;
	m_iMaxCount = _iResizeCount;
}

We added an assertion to check if inserted size was smaller or equal to the current max size. The rest of the function is just changing phrases to match the class implementation.

While there are functionality implemented, we still can’t do things like array[1] = 2. We want to implement our dynamic array to be able to express data using [] operator.
One way of doing it could be like this.

int CArr::operator[](int idx)
{
	return m_pInt[idx];

}

It returns the data residing inside that index. However in situations such as

arr[i] = 10;

its not going to work at all. The only thing that it does right now is copying the returned data to a temporary space and copying that as a result. If we want to access the original place, we need pointers.

int* CArr::operator[](int idx)
{
	return m_pInt + idx;

}

This too however has its problems.

int* p = arr[1];
*arr[1] = 20;

It works as we hoped but with different syntax. Ultimately we want to access the original variable as itself. Reference fits in perfectly.

int& CArr::operator[](int idx)
{
	return m_pInt[idx];

}

By returning the result as a reference, even though the result is saved inside a temporary memory space (which all function does when returning), the result itself directly gets translated as the original variable that we wanted by the compiler.

Function Template

Before we go implementing new features to our dynamic array, lets look at whats known as a Function Template. We learn just the basic of function template for now and cover advance topic later.

int Add(int a, int b){
	return a + b;
}
float Add(float a, float b){
	return a + b;
}
double Add(double a, double b){
	return a + b;
}
...

This is just a waste repeating same structure of function just because the returning and recieving data type is different. Function Template works around this problem by preparing an template for compiler to generate functions according to the given type.

template<typename T>
T Add(T a, T b){
	return a + b;
}

int main(){
	Add<int>(3, 4);
	Add<float>(3.0f, 4.0f);
}

This is how you make a Function Template. The keyword “typename” can be replaced with “class” but for clarity we mostly use “typename”. The word “T” represents the input data type given from the user. As the name suggest, Function Template is just a “template”. We do not consider it as normal “function”. If we don’t call this templated function, compiler considers it non-existing. Calling a template function works with using <T> after the function name. T can be any data type including custom data type.
Function Template has various features that we will not cover for now but you can sense that using this feature allows us to write less repetitive code just because we need different data type the same execution.

Class Template

Our Dynamic Array currently can only save int type array is its member variable. We would really want to decouple the int type from our array and make it so that any data type is possible for our array. Using Template is perfect for this occasion. Without it we would have been writing the same code with different type constantly. With Class Template, just calling them with any data type will generate the class with that specific data type.

template <typename T>
class CArr
{
private:
	T*		m_pData;
	int		m_iCount;
	int		m_iMaxCount;

public:
	void push_back(const T& _Data);	// To avoid unnecessary copy of big struct
	void resize(int _iResizeCount);

	T& operator[] (int idx);
public:
	CArr();
	~CArr();
};

This is the result converting the original int dynamic array class into a class template that can cover any type. Nothing change drastically, other than switching int to template type T. Now we need to change our implementation inside our .cpp file, which we will remove them entirely and paste it inside the header file. This is necessary for class template to work and here’s why.
Lets say we had our implementation inside our cpp file. main.cpp will be including the header file for our template class. At this point there is no class existing, just some template ready to generate it. When we call our class instance from our main.cpp with float, comiler knows that it needs to generate a float type class from the header that main.cpp included. However, compiler has no idea what to do with the implementation inside our cpp file. cpp file is not connected in any way to the main.cpp so it just stays at type T; Sure they both use the same header, but that does not confirm that they share information with each other.

So now we know that we need to implement our class template member function inside our header file. Syntax wise it would look something like this.

// no return types for constructor, destructor and so on
template <typename T>
Return_type Class_Name<T>::Function_Name()
{
	...
	some execution
	...
}

All we have to do is switch every int that we need to change into T and thats it.

#include <iostream>
#include "Arr/CArr.h"

int main(int argc, char** argv) {

	CArr<int> carr;
	carr.push_back(10);
	carr.push_back(20);
	carr.push_back(30);
	
	carr[1] = 11;
	printf("%d\n", carr[1]);

	CArr<float> carr_F;
	carr_F.push_back(10.0f);
	carr_F.push_back(20.0f);
	carr_F.push_back(30.0f);

	carr_F[1] = 11.1f;
	printf("%lf\n", carr_F[1]);

	// delete gets called automatically when out of scope -> destructor
	return 0;
}

With this main(), we generated two classes (one being int and other being float) using class template funtionality.

End

[Reference]
아소트락 2021 C/C++ 강의

item.title: [AssortRock_2021_C++_Course] Small Project : Linked List Using Class
item.author: ljheric7@gmail.com (Eric Lim)
item.description:
Basic C/C++

유튜브 무료강의 플레이리스트인 “C언어/C++ 무료강의 [2021년 특강]“의 영상을 통해 배운 내용 정리

Linked List

This time we will be making Linked List from Dynamic Allocation chapter using class. Furthermore we will add advance features as we go along implementing this class.

We already know how class template works, so we will design it that way from the start.

struct tListNode{
    int         iData;
    tListNode*  pNext;
};

class CList{
    private:
        tListNode*  m_pHead;
        int         m_iCount;
};

We used struct for our node data type. Technically we can use class due to the fact that struct and class works almost the same way in C++ (except the difference with visibility when not stated). In C++ struct can do everything that class can do, and the reason why we differentiate these two is for backwards compatibility with C.
For most cases, struct is used for simple data structure with no complex features needed. For instance, Vec2 can be defined as struct with two floats. It’s possible to use a class and add some math operation but thats just overkill.

Back to our topic, with the given structure that we defined, we need to template them for dynamic data type.

template <typename T>
struct tListNode{
    T data;
    tListNode* pPrev;
    tListNode* pNext;
};

This time we added pPrev to link previous item inside the list. One thing to keep in mind is that this structure is now templated, meaning that it does not exist until it’s called with specific data type. Templated class or anything templated should get called as className<T> X;. Then is tListNode* pNext; OK ? Due to the fact that its inside itself, there’s no problem with this syntax. We will however write it with <T> for clarity.

template <typename T>
class CList{
private:
	tListNode<T>*	m_pHead;
	tListNode<T>*	m_pTail;
	int				m_iCount;		

public:
	void push_back(const T& _data);
	void push_front(const T& _data);

public:
	CList();
	~CList();
};

Nothing new, we just changed every data type that needs to be templated to T. We also added m_pTail that points to the end of the list.

template <typename T>
CList<T>::CList() : m_pHead(nullptr), m_pTail(nullptr), m_iCount(0) {
}

template <typename T>
CList<T>::~CList() {
	tListNode<T>* pTarget = m_pHead;

	while (pTarget) {
		tListNode<T>* pNextTarget = pTarget->pNext;
		delete pTarget;
		pTarget = pNextTarget;
	}
	m_iCount = 0;
}

We edited Initialize() and Release() to constructor and destructor. Implementation detail has no big difference to its previous example from Dynamic Allocation.


template <typename T>
void CList<T>::push_back(const T& _data) {
	tListNode<T>* pNewNode = new tListNode<T>(_data, nullptr, nullptr);
	if (nullptr == m_pHead) {
		m_pHead = pNewNode;
		m_pTail = pNewNode;
	}
	else {
		m_pTail->pNext = pNewNode;
		pNewNode->pPrev = m_pTail;
		m_pTail = pNewNode;
	}
	++m_iCount;
}

template <typename T>
void CList<T>::push_front(const T& _data){
	// linking to original first item (both way)
	tListNode<T>* pNewNode = new tListNode<T>(_data, nullptr, m_pHead);
	m_pHead->pPrev = pNewNode;

	// update m_pHead to new node
	m_pHead = pNewNode;
	++m_iCount;
}

Implementation for push_back() and push_front() changed a bit to work with pPrev linking backwards. Our class has m_pTail that points to the last item inside the list, so our implementation for these functions can use it to simplify some parts of code.

Unlike the code from previous chapter, we allocate new temporary nodes using new. We also use constructor to initialize the values of these nodes (struct can also have constructor).

template <typename T>
struct tListNode {
	T				data;
	tListNode<T>*	pPrev;
	tListNode<T>*	pNext; 

    // Constructor
	tListNode() : data(), pPrev(nullptr), pNext(nullptr) {}
    // Constructor using input parameters
	tListNode(const T& _data, tListNode<T>* _pPrev, tListNode<T>* _pNext) :
		data(_data), pPrev(_pPrev), pNext(_pNext) {}
};

With this we can avoid writing codes like

    tListNode<T>* pNewNode = new tListNode<T>;
    pNewNode.data = _data;
    pNewNode.pPrev =  nullptr;
    pNewNode.pNext =  m_pHead;

Thats all for this part of the post.

End

[Reference]
아소트락 2021 C/C++ 강의

item.title: [AssortRock_2021_C++_Course] New & Delete
item.author: ljheric7@gmail.com (Eric Lim)
item.description:
Basic C/C++

유튜브 무료강의 플레이리스트인 “C언어/C++ 무료강의 [2021년 특강]“의 영상을 통해 배운 내용 정리

New

C++ way of saying “malloc”

new is a “new” keyword added to C++ for heap allocation. It essentially replaces malloc (exceptions exists) for heap allocation.

#include <iostream>
int main(){
	int* pint = new int;
	*p = 10;
	printf("%d\n", *p);	// prints 10
}

Unlike malloc, using new is quite simple, just call it with a data type following it and its done. Size needs to get mentioned when allocating for continuous memory like an array.

int main(){
	int* parr = new int[10];

	for(int i = 0; i < 10; ++i){
		*(parr + i) = i;
	}

	return 0;
}

With [] operator, new does not need sizeof() function to specify size for itself.

Delete

free() was used to free up the memory allocated from malloc(), so its natural to assume there exists a counterpart for new, and thats delete.

int main(){
	int* p = new int;
	int* parr = new int[10];
	int a = 1;

	delete a;		//	ERROR
	delete p;		//	OK
	delete[] p;		//	OK
	return 0;
}

Like new, using delete is not that hard at all. Variables that were not allocated from heap memory will return an error if you try to delete them. For continuously allocated memory, just like new, delete [] dose the job.

Why use this keyword instead of malloc?

C++ presented them as a replacement.
Also we need to guarantee that constructors get called when instance gets allocated.

...
some class with 50 byte
...

int main(){
	class_type instance;
	class_type* allocated_instance = new class_type;
	class_type* allocated_instance = (class_type*)malloc(sizeof(class_type));
	return 0;
}

malloc() will return 50bytes of heap memory that reads as class_type. It does not know anything about constructors or member functions at all. new gets class_type as input, so it knows what we are allocating, so no problem with calling constructors when allocating. delete works the same, unlike free() delete will call destructor as it frees allocated heap memory.

delete[] will call destructor for ever item in the list. Inside heap memory, a bits is representing the end of an allocated memory just like a string; You don’t need to worry about not releasing 100% of allocated memory.
{: .prompt-info }

End

[Reference]
아소트락 2021 C/C++ 강의

item.title: [AssortRock_2021_C++_Course] Class (2)
item.author: ljheric7@gmail.com (Eric Lim)
item.description:
Basic C/C++

유튜브 무료강의 플레이리스트인 “C언어/C++ 무료강의 [2021년 특강]“의 영상을 통해 배운 내용 정리

Destructor

Class instance is created using Constructor. When it gets deleted it uses whats called Destructor.

class myClass{
public:
	int a;
	// Constructor
	myClass() : a(10){
		printf("Constructor called");
	}
	// Destructor
	~myClass(){
		printf("Destructor called");
	}
};

int main(){
	myClass x;
	return 0;
}

Result

"Constructor called"
"Destructor called"

Destructor is declared as its class name wirh ” ~ “ at the front. Similar to Constructors, Destructor does not have any return type. Default Destructor also works identical as constructor.
Whats different is that

  • destructor does not take any input parameter
  • There can be only ONE destructor
  • destructor can’t be declared as const, volatile or static.
    However it can be used to destruct instance declared as those keywords.

Destructor gets called whenever an instance is deleted, out of scope, or program shutting down. Member variable that was allocated from heap memory relies on Destructor to clean them up.

Code bellow is a class representation of Dynamic Array from previous post. Tried to fill in as much as possible to show every aspect coverd in this post.

class tArr{
private:
	void Reallocate(){
		// 1. reallocate for more space ( max * 2 )
		int* pNew = (int*)malloc(sizeof(int) * iMaxCount * 2);
		// 2. copy original data to newly aquired Darr
		for (int i = 0; i < iCount; ++i) {
			pNew[i] = pInt[i];
		}
		// 3. free original Darr & point towards new Darr
		free(pInt);
		pInt = pNew;
		iMaxCount = iMaxCount * 2;
	}

public:
	int* pInt;
	int iCount;
	int iMaxCount;

	tArr() : iCount(0), iMaxCount(2){
		pInt = (int*)malloc(sizeof(int)*2);
	}

	tArr(int reserve_size){
		pInt = (int*)malloc(sizeof(int)*reserve_size);
		iCount = 0;
		iMaxCount = reserve_size;
	}
	
	~tArr()
	{
		free(pInt);
		iCount = 0;
		iMaxCount = 0;
	}

	void PushBack(int _data){
		if (iCount >= iMaxCount) {
			// expand space
			Reallocate();
		}
		// data input
		pInt[iCount++] = _data;
	}
}

Class definitions mostly sits inside a header file. When we discussed about header files, we mentioned that along with global variables, functions declaration should sit inside corresponding cpp file for better readability and for preventing same function copied in every translation including said header file. Functions inside Class however is slightly different. We will talk about this more throughly after we learn inline functionality in the future. {: .prompt-info }

Operator OverLoad

Consider the following situation.

class A{
	int a;
	public:
		A():a(1){}
		A(int _a) : a(_a){}

		~A(){
			printf("Called Destructor");
		}
};

int main(){
	int a = 1;
	int b = 2;
	a = b;

	A x;
	A y(10);
	x = y;
}

a = b will copy the value from b to a. x = y should have the same effect. However compiler has no idea how to handle it. Class A is created by us, so unlike normal data type like int, compiler has no clue how assign operator would work on such thing. Compiler automatically genereates whats know as Assign Operator.

A& operator=(const A& _Other){
	a = _Other.a;
	return *this;
}

Basically all it did was overloading existing function = to work with this class. Return type is a reference type of our class and returns *this. “this” is a keyword representing the instance that called this function. For x = y, x is considered to call the function =, so this refers to x.
Why do we need to return *this?

class A{
public:
	int a;
	A(): a(0){}
	~A(){}
	A& operator=(const A& _Other){
		a = _Other.a;
		return *this;
	}
};
int main(){
	A x;
	A y;
	A z;
	x = y = z;
}

Remeber that result returned by the function disappears after function ends? With that in mind, lets say we didn’t return *this. y = z is a function call from y calling overloaded function = and _Other being z. After that function call the result would be z’s content copied to y, but we didn’t return anything so now the result is just void now (even though y’s content have changed). Now we end up with x = (void) which just doesn’t make any sense. So we need *this to return the end result, but only that would cause unnecessary copy happening( the = operator). This is why our assign operator returns with a reference data type. We end up returning a reference to our copied original data, which is way more efficient than copying the whole context every time.

Other operators such as + and - can also be overrided in to your class’s need. It may have different context than normal mathematical operation; You decide how it works.

Copy Constructor

class A{
public:
	int a;
	A(): a(0){}
	~A(){}
	A(const A* _Other){
		a = _Other.a;
	}
};
int main(){
	A x;
	A y = x; // copy
	A z(x);	 // copy
	z = yl	 // assign
}

복사 생성자의 사용법이다. 참고로 아래와 같은 경우 둘은 다른 의미를 지닌다. *(1)*의 경우 복사 생성자를 이용한 것이고, *(2)*의 경우 생성 후 대입을 한 것 이다. 또한 생성자와 소멸자처럼 디폴트로 생성되는 Default Copy Constructor도 존재한다.


// (1)
	A x;
	A y = x; // 생성과 동시에 대입-> 즉 복사생성자 그래서 컴파일러가 자동으로 "A y(x);" 로 변환함
// (2)
	A x;
	A y;
	x = y;

참고로 복사생성자도 생성자이기 때문에 디폴트 생성자를 컴파일러가 만들어주지 않는다. 그래서 복사생성자를 만들면 생성자를 따로 만들어야된다.

End

[Reference]
아소트락 2021 C/C++ 강의
